metadata.title: Historic Firsts: Aeromedical Evacuation and the Transportation Isolation System

body_text.text: This short communication highlights the US Air Force's recent success with having their aeromedical evacuation crews use the Transportation Isolation System for the first time operationally to transport patients positive for coronavirus disease 2019.
body_text.section: A B S T R A C T

body_text.text: Published by Elsevier Inc. on behalf of Air Medical Journal Associates.
body_text.section: A B S T R A C T

body_text.text: Aeromedical evacuation (AE) has a long and storied history that dates to the early part of the 20th century. 1 The Air Force's AE system has been fundamental in transporting war-injured patients since World War II. 2 The AE system provides en route care and transportation to patients while flying to and from medical facilities. Currently, the AE system is composed of 4 active duty AE squadrons, 9 Air National Guard squadrons, and 18 Air Force Reserve AE squadrons. 3 The AE system has revolutionized battlefield medicine; AE continues to advance, evolve, and adapt to meet emerging transport needs in new conflicts, medicine, and flight. 2 Recently, AE made headlines and history by conducting the first operational mission using the Transport Isolation System (TIS) to transport patients positive for coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). 4 The TIS is an infectious disease containment unit that can be used to provide medical care to patients while in-flight. 5 The TIS was originally developed in support of the Ebola outbreak in Africa; during the outbreak, the Department of Defense ordered 25 of the isolation units for the military. 6 It passed it is safe to fly testing in December 2014. 5 The unit is designed to minimize and protect the aircrew, medical attendants, and the aircraft from exposure to infectious and/or contagious diseases. 5 Initial training on the TIS takes 4 days and includes training on TIS familiarization, personal protective equipment, infection control procedures, donning and doffing protocols, practicing patient loading and unloading procedures, and patient transport and care. 5, 7 The training can also include simulated patients, simulated patient care, and simulated in-flight transport. 7 The basic version of the TIS system has 2 isolation modules (each one weighing 1,455 lb) and 1 antechamber module (weighing 1,285 lb), all of which are under negative pressure ( Figure 1) . 5, 8 The modules are placed on aircraft pallets and can be used on C-17, C-130H, and C-130J aircraft ( Figure 2) . 5, 8 These pallets have been retrofitted with watertight enclosures and high-efficiency particulate air filtration systems, all intake and outtake air is high-efficiency particulate air filtered, which is designed to contain infectious pathogens. 5, 8 The antechamber provides a safe space for the AE crew to don and doff personal protective equipment before and after patient care. 5 Each TIS system can accommodate 4 ambulatory or 2 litter patients; C-17s have the capability to transport 2 TIS systems at a time. 5 The full medical support team for a TIS includes an AE crew (usually 2 nurses and 3 AE technicians), a critical care air transport team, infectious disease physicians and technicians, and TIS operators. 9 On April 8, 2020, a warning order was issued by the US Transportation Command that a TIS-trained AE crew would be needed for a mission within 24 hours. 9 On April 10, 2020, the Air Mobility Command's newly released COVID-19 patient movement plan was followed, and the first operational flight was performed using the TIS. 9 The mission took place on a C-17 and safely transported 3 US government contractors who had tested positive for COVID-19 from Afghanistan to Ramstein Air Base, Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany. 9 On July 17, 2020, the TIS was used to fly a COVID-19 patient from the Indo-Pacific region to Travis Air Force Base, Fairfield, CA. 10 This was the first TIS mission in support of the US Indo-Pacific Command area. 10 However, this marked the 18th employment of the TIS for COVID-19 patients since its first operational use on April 10, 2020. 10 These historic flights highlight part of the US military's rapid response to meet the challenges of COVID-19. Having the AE capability of safely flying and caring for patients with infectious and contagious diseases is a significant accomplishment. The TIS has proven to be successful operationally and will be ready to meet the challenges presented by any future high-consequence infectious diseases.
body_text.section: A B S T R A C T
